facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 251 of 1954 is an appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 22, 1952, of the Punjab High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 251 of 1954. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 22, 1952, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Regular First Appeal No. 1/E of 1947 arising out of the judgment and decree dated July 1, 1947, of the Court of SubJudge, Ambala in Suit No. 239 of 1946.

facts.text: Punjab High Court passed judgment and decree on April 22, 1952, in Civil Regular First Appeal No. 1/E of 1947, reversing the decree of SubJudge Ambala.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 22, 1952, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Regular First Appeal No. 1/E of 1947 arising out of the judgment and decree dated July 1, 1947, of the Court of SubJudge, Ambala in Suit No. 239 of 1946. Tarachand Brijmohan Lal, for the appellant.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge, Ambala passed decree on July 1, 1947, in Suit No. 239 of 1946 in favour of the plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 22, 1952, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Regular First Appeal No. 1/E of 1947 arising out of the judgment and decree dated July 1, 1947, of the Court of SubJudge, Ambala in Suit No. 239 of 1946.

facts.text: Certificate for appeal granted by Division Bench on December 19, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal has been preferred on the strength of a certificate granted by the Division Bench on December 19, 1952. The facts material for the purpose of this appeal may number be shortly stated One Lala Beni Pershad died in the year 1910 leaving him surviving his widow Mst. Daropadi  defendant respondent No. 2  and two sons by her, namely, Gokul Chand  defendant respondent No. 1  and Raghunath Das  plaintiff appellant  who was then a minor.

facts.text: Lala Beni Pershad died in 1910 leaving widow Mst. Daropadi (respondent No. 2) and sons Gokul Chand (respondent No. 1) and Raghunath Das (plaintiff appellant, minor).

anchor.surface_text: The facts material for the purpose of this appeal may number be shortly stated One Lala Beni Pershad died in the year 1910 leaving him surviving his widow Mst. Daropadi  defendant respondent No. 2  and two sons by her, namely, Gokul Chand  defendant respondent No. 1  and Raghunath Das  plaintiff appellant  who was then a minor. Lala Beni Pershad left companysiderable moveable properties including many G. P. Notes and also various immoveable properties including agricul- tural land, gardens and houses.

facts.text: Family continued joint until disputes arose between brothers in 1934.

anchor.surface_text: After his death the family companytinued to be joint until disputes and. differences arose between the two brothers in 1934. Eventually oil November 12, 1934, the two brothers executed an agreement referring their disputes relating to the partition of the family properties to the arbitration of Lala Ramji Das who was a companymon relation.

facts.text: On November 12, 1934, brothers executed agreement referring partition disputes to arbitration of Lala Ramji Das.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually oil November 12, 1934, the two brothers executed an agreement referring their disputes relating to the partition of the family properties to the arbitration of Lala Ramji Das who was a companymon relation. It is alleged that the respondent Gokul Chand had disposed of part of the   F. P. Notes and that at the date of the reference to arbitration G. P. Notes of the value of Rs. 26,500 only were held by Gokul Chand, as the Karta of the family.

facts.text: Gokul Chand held G.P. Notes of value Rs. 26,500 at date of arbitration reference as Karta.

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged that the respondent Gokul Chand had disposed of part of the   F. P. Notes and that at the date of the reference to arbitration G. P. Notes of the value of Rs. 26,500 only were held by Gokul Chand, as the Karta of the family. On June 21, 1936, the arbitrator made an award which was signed by both the, brothers statedly ill token of their acceptance thereof.

facts.text: Arbitrator made award on June 21, 1936, signed by brothers, registered July 28, 1936.

anchor.surface_text: On June 21, 1936, the arbitrator made an award which was signed by both the, brothers statedly ill token of their acceptance thereof. The award was registered on July 28, 1936. By that award the arbitrator divided the imoveable, properties and shops as therein mentioned.

facts.text: Award directed G.P. Notes Rs.13,300 to Gokul Chand and Daropadi, Rs.13,200 to Raghunath Das and Daropadi; interest to Daropadi till death; Gokul to pay Rs.20,000 to Raghunath in installments.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the P. Notes the arbitrator directed and awarded that out of the G. P. Notes of the value of Rs. 26,500, which then stood in the name of Gokul Chand, G. P. Notes of the value of Rs. 13,300 should be entered into the names of Gokul Chand and Mst. Daropadi and the remaining Notes of the value of Rs. 13,200 should be endorsed in the names of Raghunatb Das and Mst. Daropadi and that till her death Mst. Daropadi should alone be entitled to the interest on the entire G. P. Notes of the value of Its. 26,500 and that after her death Gokul Chand would be the owner of the  X. P. Notes of the value of Rs. 13,300 and Raghunath Das of G. P. Notes of the value of Rs. 13,200.

facts.text: On August 31, 1936, Gokul Chand applied to District Judge Ambala to file award under Sch II para 20 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: On August 31, 1936, Gokul Chand applied to the District Judge, Ambala under paragraph 20, of Schedule 11 to the Code of Civil Procedure for filing the award.

facts.text: District Judge on November 18, 1936, filed modified award and passed decree.

anchor.surface_text: By an order made on November 18, 1936, the District Judge directed the award as modified by the companypromise to be filed and passed a decree in accordance with the terms of the award thus modified.

facts.text: Raghunath Das applied for execution of decree on November 15, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: On November 15, 1939, Raghunath Das made an application to the companyrt of the District judge for execution of the decree.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge on December 23, 1942, dismissed execution application accepting Gokul's jurisdiction objection.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge on December 23, 1942, accepted Gokul Chands plea and dismissed the execution application.

facts.text: High Court Single Judge on April 5, 1944, allowed Raghunath's appeal against dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by Raghunath Das to the High Court a learned Single Judge on April 5, 1944, accepted the appeal, but on Letters Patent Appeal filed by Gokul Chand the Division Bench on March 15, 1945, reversed the order of the Single Judge and restored the order of dismissal passed by the Subordinate Judge.

facts.text: High Court Division Bench on March 15, 1945, reversed Single Judge and restored dismissal of execution.

anchor.surface_text: but on Letters Patent Appeal filed by Gokul Chand the Division Bench on March 15, 1945, reversed the order of the Single Judge and restored the order of dismissal passed by the Subordinate Judge.

facts.text: Raghunath Das instituted Suit No. 80 of 1945 on August 21, 1945, for Rs. 7,310-11-3 balance of Rs.20,000.

anchor.surface_text: Having failed to obtain the relief granted to him by the decree passed upon the award on the ground of defect of jurisdiction in the companyrt which passed the decree and companysequently for want of jurisdiction in the executing companyrt, Raghunath Das, on August 21, 1945, instituted Suit No. 80 of 1945 against Gokul Chand for the recovery of Rs. 7,310-11-3 being the balance with interest remaining due to him out of the said sum of Rs. 20,000, awarded in his favour.

facts.text: Senior Subordinate Judge Ambala decreed Suit No.80/1945 on December 22, 1945, in favour of Raghunath Das; no appeal, final.

anchor.surface_text: Gokul Chand raised a number of pleas but eventually all his pleas were negatived and the senior Subordinate Judge, Ambala, by his judgment pronounced on December 22, 1945, decreed the suit in favour of Raghunath Das. Gokul Chand did number file any appeal therefrom and companysequently that decree became final and binding as between the parties thereto.

facts.text: Raghunath Das filed Suit No. 239 of 1946 on June 5, 1946, claiming transfer of G.P. Notes Rs.13,200 or payment.

anchor.surface_text: On June 5, 1946, Raghunath Das filed in the companyrt of the Senior Subordinate Judge, Ambala a suit being Suit No. 239 of 1946 out of which the present appeal has arisen. In this suit Raghunath Das claimed that Gokul Chand be ordered to transfer G. P. Notes of the value of Rs. 13,200 out of the P. Notes of the value of Rs. 26,500 to Raghunath Das and Mst. Daropadi by means of endorsement or some other legal way, to get them entered into the Government registers and to make them over to Raghunath Das, the plaintiff.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge decreed Suit 239/1946 on July 1, 1947, holding not barred by limitation or O2 R2 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate Judge accordingly decreed the suit in favour of Raghunath Das.

facts.text: Punjab High Court Division Bench on April 22, 1952, allowed appeal, dismissed suit as barred by Art.49 Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel appearing for Gokul Chand urged that the suit was one for the recovery of -other specific moveable property... The High Court held that the suit was governed by Art. 49... allowed the appeal and dismissed the suit as barred by limitation.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds suit governed by Art.120 Limitation Act, not Art.49, and time excluded under s.14.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the decision of the High Court as companyrect... Raghunath Das is entitled to the benefit of s. 14  1  of the Indian Limitation Act and the period here in before mentioned being excluded, there can be numberdoubt that the suit was filed well within the prescribed period of limitation

facts.text: Supreme Court remands case to High Court for decision on O2 R2 issue.

anchor.surface_text: The suit should, therefore, go back to the High Court for determination of that issue. The result, therefore, is that we accept the appeal, set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court and remand the case back to the High Court for a decision on issue No.

Article 49. provides three years period of limitation I04 for a suit for other specific moveable property or for companysation for wrongful taking or injuring or wrongfully detaining the same and this period of three years begins to run from when the property is wrongfully taken or injured or when the detainers possession becomes unlawful .

arguments.claim: Suit not for specific movable property but for partition/division of joint/tenants-in-common movable property; governed by Art.120

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the decision of the High Court as companyrect... That expression is apt only to companyer a suit wherein the plaintiff can allege that he is entitled to certain specific moveable property... In short such a suit is numberhing but a suit for partition or division of the moveable properties held jointly or as tenants-in-common by the parties and there being numberspecific Article applicable to such a suit it must be governed by Art. 120.
The respondent contends that the above section has numberapplication to the facts of his case. We do number think that such companytention is well-founded.

arguments.court_reasoning: Execution proceedings were civil proceedings on same cause of action (enforce award rights), prosecuted diligently in good faith in court unable due to jurisdiction defect in original decree court

arguments.claim: Execution proceedings founded on same cause of action as suit; prosecuted in good faith in court unable to entertain due to jurisdiction defect; time excluded under s.14(1)

anchor.surface_text: The execution proceedings initiated by Raghunath Das were certainly civil proceedings... The execution proceedings were founded upon his claim to enforce his rights declared under the decree upon the award. The cause of action in the present suit is also for enforcement of the same right... Therefore, the defect of jurisdiction in the companyrt that passed the decree became, as it were, attached to the decree itself and the executing companyrt companyld number entertain the execution proceeding on account of the same defect.

arguments.claim: Suit within limitation under Art.120 with s.14 exclusion

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion Raghunath Das is entitled to the benefit of s. 14  1  of the Indian Limitation Act and the period here in before mentioned being excluded, there can be numberdoubt that the suit was filed well within the prescribed period of limitation

arguments.claim: Issue of O2 R2 bar not decided; remand to High Court

anchor.surface_text: In the view it took on the question of limitation the Division Bench did number companysider it necessary to go into or give any decision on the other issue, namely, as to whether the suit was barred by 0. 2, r. 2.

holdings.text: The suit is not one for specific movable property under Article 49 of the Limitation Act but a suit for partition or division of movable properties held jointly or as tenants-in-common governed by Article 120.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the decision of the High Court as correct. The High Court overlooked the fact that so far as the G. P. Notes were concerned the decree upon the award only declared the rights of the parties. Under the decree Raghunath Das was entitled to have G. P. Notes of the value of Rs. 13,200 endorsed in the names of himself and Mst. Daropadi out of the G. P. Notes of the value of Rs. 26,500. The award or the decree thereon did not actually divide the P. Notes by specifying which particular G. P. Notes were to be endorsed in the names of Gokul Chand and Mst. Daropadi or which of them were to be endorsed in the names of Raghunath Das and his mother.

holdings.reasoning_summary: G.P. Notes not specifically divided by award or decree; plaintiff seeks court-directed allocation of undivided share from joint/tenants-in-common property; distinguishes suits for wrongful detention of specific chattels; follows precedent on heir's share suits (Mohomed Riasat Ali).

holdings.text: Execution proceedings were founded on the same cause of action as the present suit, prosecuted with due diligence and in good faith in a court unable to entertain it for defect of jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The execution proceedings initiated by Raghunath Das were certainly civil proceedings and there can be no doubt that he prosecuted such civil proceedings with due diligence and good faith... The execution proceedings were founded upon his claim to enforce his rights declared under the decree upon the award. The cause of action in the present suit is also for enforcement of the same right... Therefore, the defect of jurisdiction in the court that passed the decree became, as it were, attached to the decree itself and the executing court could not entertain the execution proceeding on account of the same defect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both proceedings enforce rights under award decree; execution failed due to original court's jurisdiction defect making decree nullity, transmitted to executing court; diligence shown by appeals up to Division Bench.

holdings.text: Raghunath Das is entitled to the benefit of Section 14(1) of the Limitation Act excluding the period from November 15, 1939 to March 15, 1945 spent in execution proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 (1) of the Indian Limitation Act runs as follows 14 (1) In computing the period of limitation prescribed for any suit, the time during which the plaintiff has been prosecuting with, due diligence another civil proceeding... The respondent contends that the above section has no application to the facts of his case. We do not think that such contention is well-founded.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Execution qualifies as 'another civil proceeding' under s.14(1); satisfies all conditions: same cause, good faith, diligence, jurisdictional defect.

holdings.text: The suit was filed well within the prescribed period of limitation under Article 120 with exclusion under Section 14(1).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion Raghunath Das is entitled to the benefit of s. 14 (1) of the Indian Limitation Act and the period herein before mentioned being excluded, there can be no doubt that the suit was filed well within the prescribed period of limitation and the judgment of the Division Bench cannot be sustained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Art.120 (6 years from accrual); excludes ~5.5 years under s.14; suit filed June 5, 1946 within time post-exclusion.

holdings.text: The Division Bench did not decide whether the suit was barred by Order 2 Rule 2 CPC; case remanded to High Court for determination of that issue.

anchor.surface_text: In the view it took on the question of limitation the Division Bench did not consider it necessary to go into or give any decision on the other issue, namely, as to whether the suit was barred by 0. 2, r. 2. The suit should, therefore, go back to the High Court for determination of that issue.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court decided limitation first and dismissed without addressing O2R2; Supreme Court reverses on limitation, requires decision on remaining issue.

precedents.citation: Gopal Chandra Bose v. Surendra Nath Dutt  1

anchor.surface_text: These considerations clearly distinguish this case from the case of Gopal Chandra Bose v. Surendra Nath Dutt  1  on which the High Court relied because in that case the defendant had numberright to or interest in the G. P. Notes in question and had numberright to retain possession thereof.

precedents.case_name: Gopal Chandra Bose v. Surendra Nath Dutt
precedents.cited_proposition: Defendant had no right to or interest in the G. P. Notes and no right to retain possession thereof so Art. 49 applies.

precedents.citation: Mohomed Riasat Ali v. Mussumat Hasin Banu  1

anchor.surface_text: See Mohomed Riasat Ali v. Mussumat Hasin Banu  1 . The only difference between the facts of that case and those of the present case is that here the rights of the parties had been declared by the decree upon the award but that circumstance does number appear to us to make any material difference in the application of the principle laid down by the Judicial Committee.

precedents.case_name: Mohomed Riasat Ali v. Mussumat Hasin Banu
precedents.cited_proposition: a suit by an heir against other heirs to recover his share of the moveable estate of a deceased person is not one for specific moveable property wrongfully taken such as is contemplated by Art 49, but is governed by Art. 120

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that we accept the appeal, set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court and remand the case back to the High Court for a decision on issue No.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal accepted; High Court judgment and decree set aside on limitation issue; case remanded to High Court for decision on whether suit barred by O.2 R.2 CPC
directions: set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court
remand the case back to the High Court for a decision on issue No. (bar under O.2 r.2 CPC)

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the decision of the High Court as correct. The High Court overlooked the fact that so far as the G. P. Notes were concerned the decree upon the award only declared the rights of the parties. Under the decree Raghunath Das was entitled to have G. P. Notes of the value of Rs. 13,200 endorsed in the names of himself and Mst. Daropadi out of the G. P. Notes of the value of Rs. 26,500. The award or the decree thereon did not actually divide the P. Notes by specifying which particular G. P. Notes were to be endorsed in the names of Gokul Chand and Mst. Daropadi or which of them were to be endorsed in the names of Raghunath Das and his mother.

anchor.surface_text: The execution proceedings initiated by Raghunath Das were certainly civil proceedings and there can be no doubt that he prosecuted such civil proceedings with due diligence and good faith... The execution proceedings were founded upon his claim to enforce his rights declared under the decree upon the award. The cause of action in the present suit is also for enforcement of the same right... Therefore, the defect of jurisdiction in the court that passed the decree became, as it were, attached to the decree itself and the executing court could not entertain the execution proceeding on account of the same defect.

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 (1) of the Indian Limitation Act runs as follows 14 (1) In computing the period of limitation prescribed for any suit, the time during which the plaintiff has been prosecuting with, due diligence another civil proceeding... The respondent contends that the above section has no application to the facts of his case. We do not think that such contention is well-founded.
The result, therefore, is that we accept the appeal, set aside the judgment and decree of the High Court and remand the case back to the High Court for a decision on issue No.
